Award.AwardTitle: Physics of Bacteria Living in Gels: Host-Bacteria Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal addresses the fundamental puzzle of how Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) breaches the protective mucus barrier to reach the epithelial cell surface and colonize in the extreme acidic environment of the stomach. The studies proposed here will advance the fundamental physics underlying bacterial motion and aggregation in a viscoelastic gel, and elucidate the influence of shape on motility and colonization. Chemotactic measurements of bacteria moving in microfluidic devices with multiple chemical gradients across mucin/mucus layers on gastric cells will contribute to the development of a useful ex vivo, biomimetic model.

Many bacteria, like those in the gastrointestinal tract, have to negotiate mucosal barriers to establish colonies. In particular, Helicobacter pylori, the bacterium that causes ulcers, gastritis and gastric cancer faces the additional challenge of overcoming the acidic environment. Previous work from the PI's group established that H. pylori uses the same biochemical strategy of urea hydrolysis to neutralize the acid and elevate the pH for both survival in the stomach and to swim across by triggering a gel-solution transition. Recent studies with mutants having cell shape alterations have shown that the helical shape is advantageous in establishing colonies in agar gels. Preliminary bacteria tracking microscopy and resistive force theory based modeling show that the distribution of swimming speeds is due to polydispersity of shape and size, along with a biphasic temporal variation of speed, and that the helical shape provides added propulsion in a viscous mucin solution leading to a faster swimming speed. Innovative imaging techniques will be used to investigate bacterial motility and the changes that the bacterium causes in the host gel by quantitative measurements of pH changes and alterations in local micro-rheology of its environment. The rheological studies of bacteria infected gels will be characterized using oscillatory shear rheology. Microfluidic geometries will be designed to mimic the gastric mucus environment under ex-vivo conditions, layering substrates with epithelial cells covered with mucus or purified mucin or gelatin or agar and establish pH or ionic gradients to examine the bacteria motility and the extent and pattern of colonization. The influence of the bacterium on the surrounding mucus /mucin will be probed by fluorescent dye binding and Atomic Force Microscopy. Comparative studies of the wild-type H. pylori with mutants with altered cell shapes or deficient in specific receptors or flagella, will make it possible to assess the effect of the many variables at play in this complex living system. The experimental studies will be complemented by computational and theoretical modeling of bacterial motility, body and flagella dynamics, chemotaxis, and pattern formation in gels to provide a quantitative understanding of the underlying physics. High school students will participate via the Summer research internship, RISE program at Boston University. Videos on bacterial motility and simple analysis tools will be developed for use in undergraduate courses and for demonstration purposes. The PI will take advantage of the diversity of the team, and the broad appeal of the research topic, to do outreach activities involving presentations to a broader audience, including local high schools, and minority and other community groups and to recruit women and minority graduate, undergraduate and high school students to participate in this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How the helical shaped stomach ulcer and cancer causing bacterium, Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) breach the highly viscoelastic protective stomach mucus barrier remains an open question. The PI, Rama Bansil and her collaborators have previously shown that this bacterium cannot swim in the highly acidic mucin gel; it can only move by utilizing the breakdown of urea to produce ammonia to elevate the pH of the mucus layer leading to de-gelation of the mucin gel. In the current project they use microscopic imaging to track the bacteria as they swim forward and reverse direction while their flagella, microscopic motor driven propellers used to swim, and cell body rotate. They complemented the experiments using computational modeling to obtain detailed insight into the swimming mechanism and how the speed varies with the shape of the cell body and arrangement of flagella.  They compared the human pathogen H. pylori which has unipolar flagella,  i.e. a bundle of flagella at one end of the body, with the very similar helicobacter, H. suis, known to infect pigs and transmitted to humans. H. suis is bipolar, having bundles of flagella at both ends of its body. These studies showed that the bipolar bacterium can swim in various modes, using both flagella bundles extended away from the body, or one bundle wrapped around the body and the other extended, or both wrapped. Interestingly the most efficient swimming is achieved when one flagella bundle is wrapped and the other extended.

 

In order to infect the stomach  the bacterium has to go across a pH barrier, as the mucus layer of the stomach is highly acidic on the side of the stomach lumen and neutral close to the cell surface.  Previous work of Bansil?s group has established that lowering pH below 4 leads to gelation of the glycoprotein known as mucin, that is responsible for the viscoelasticity and gelation of the mucus layer. To assess how the motility is influenced by varying pH and how the bacteria in turn influence the viscoelasticity of the mucus layer, they compared bacteria swimming in culture broth as well as mucin at different pHs. They found that lowering the pH leads to both an impairment of the molecular motors that propel the flagella, as well as a dramatic slowing down of speed as acidity increases, i.e. pH decreases below pH 4 the bacteria are trapped in the gel. It appears that bacteria can sense the fluidity or rigidity of their environment and rotate their flagella faster when they are stuck in the low pH mucin gel.

 

The research involves live cell digital microscopic tracking of bacteria and analyzing the tracks to obtain the swimming speed. The hydrodynamic effects of varying cell shape and flagella arrangement on swimming speed and rotation of the body were modeled using Regularized Stokeslet modeling. The combined experimental and computational modeling indicate that helical cell shape enhances H. pylori?s swimming speed through the viscoelastic gastric mucin environment by providing ~ 10-15% additional propulsion as compared to the straight-rod shaped mutants. By studying the motion of microscopic particles in mucin they found that lowering pH increases the viscosity of the medium and the effect is greater when bacteria are added. They found that human mucin isolated from a stomach tumor has the least viscosity and further decreases the most in the presence of swimming bacteria. This observation may provide some clues on how the bacterium promotes the development of tumor. 

 

The live-cell imaging methods and computational analysis used and further developed in this work are of general applicability to understanding the broader question of how bacteria swim to colonize in highly viscous media, such as soil, sludge or in the ocean. They have also studied the motion of bacteria in micron sized channels using microfluidic devices where acid and other chemicals such as urea can be added which either repel or attract the bacteria. These devices model the geometry of gastric glands which are of similar size and where cells secrete acid and other molecules guiding the motion of bacteria either towards or away from the cell surface. These studies are the first step towards eventually developing realistic model systems for testing the motion of disease causing pathogenic bacteria, as well as the microbiota in the digestive tract in the presence of secretory molecules, drugs and other substances.

 

The project supported educational and outreach activities. Multidisciplinary research training in physics and cell and microbiology was provided to both undergraduate and graduate students pursuing Ph. D. The computer programs developed in this research are of general applicability and can be used to track live cells in complex media. Outreach activities included presentations at national and international scientific meetings, as well as to K-12 students and the general public. The results of this project have been published in peer reviewed scientific journals.
